facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1958 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 480 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 15, 1958 of Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 194 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 15, 1958, of the Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 194 of 1957, arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated October 26, 1957 of Election Tribunal, Puri in Election Case No. 1/67 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated October 26, 1957, of the Election Tribunal, Puri, in Election Case No. 1/67 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant, respondent No. 1 and others were candidates for election to Orissa Legislative Assembly from Daspalla double-member constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent No. 1 were, amongst others, candidates for election to the Orissa Legislative Assembly from the Daspalla doublemember companystituency

facts.text: Daspalla constituency had a seat reserved for scheduled caste candidate; case concerns general seat contested by appellant, respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: in which a seat was reserved for a scheduled caste candidate. We are number companycerned with the election of the scheduled caste candidate. For the general seat the election was companytested by the appellant, respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 3.

facts.text: Appellant obtained 17,700 votes, respondent No. 1 obtained 15,568 votes, respondent No. 3 obtained 3,589 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained 17,700 votes, respondent No. 1 15,568 votes and respondent No. 3 3,589 votes.

facts.text: Election held on February 27, 1957; appellant declared elected on March 5, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The election was held on February 27, 1957, and the appellant was declared elected on March 5, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed election petition questioning appellant's election on various grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed an election petition questioning, on various grounds, the election -of the aPpellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the petition holding no grounds established to invalidate election.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal dismissed the petition holding that numbergrounds had been established to invalidate the election.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Orissa High Court against Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to the High Court of Orissa against the order of the Election Tribunal.

facts.text: One ground: nomination of respondent No. 3 improperly accepted as disqualified being Sarbarakar of 10 villages in Nayagarh district.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds... taken by Respondent No. 1 to invalidate the election of the appellant was that the numberination of respondent No. 3 -was improperly accepted as he was disqualified from companytesting the election being a Sarbarakar of the 10 villages in the, district of Nayagarh

facts.text: Orissa High Court held office of Sarbarakar is office of profit under State Government of Orissa; respondent No. 3 disqualified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the office of Sarbarakar was an office of profit under the State Government of Orissa. Respondent No. 3 was accordingly disqualified from being a member of the Assembly.

facts.text: High Court held acceptance of respondent No. 3's nomination did not materially affect election of returned candidate under cl. d of sub-s. 1 of s. 100 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, held that the acceptance of the numberination of respondent No. 3 had number materially affected the election of the returned candidate under el.  d  of sub- s.  1  of s. 100

facts.text: Three corrupt practice grounds urged before High Court: bribery, publication of false pamphlet Exbt. 8 about respondent No. 1, assistance from Sarpanches.

anchor.surface_text: Three grounds were urged before the High Court in support of the companytention that the appellant had been guilty of companyrupt practice. One was that of bribery the second was that the appellant and his agents had published a pamphlet, Exbt. 8, companytaining statements which were false... and the third was, the obtaining and procuring by respondent No. 1 of assistance... from Sarpanches

facts.text: High Court held first two corrupt practice grounds not established.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the first two grounds the High Court held that the same had number been established.

facts.text: High Court held Sarpanch of Grama Panchayat is person in service of Government under s.123(7)(f) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the third ground the High Court was of the opinion that a Sarpanch of the Grama Panchayat... was numbere the less a person in the service of the Government as he performed many of the governmental duties... such a person came within the provisions of s. 123 7  f  of the Act.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal, set aside appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly allowed the appeal and set aside the appellants election

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: In order to remove all doubts in the matter, we grant the appellant special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court of Orissa and proceed to deal with the appeal on that basis.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Sarpanch under Orissa Grama Panchayats Act, 1948 is not in service of Government and not revenue officer or village accountant under s.123(7)(f).

anchor.surface_text: We have been unable to find a single provision of the Orissa Act from which we companyld say that a Sarpanch is a person in the service of the Government.... a Sarpanch of the Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act is neither a revenue officer number a village accountant.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, dismissed election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the election petition of respondent No.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us unnecessary to decide whether in a case of this kind the provisions of Art. 133 1 c of the Constitution applied because, in our opinion, even if they did number apply and the High Court could number have issued a certificate, this was just the kind of case where we would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution

issues.text: The principal question for consideration is whether a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat constituted under the Orissa Act is a person in the service of the Government of the State of Orissa and belongs to the class specified in cl. f of s. 123(7)

anchor.surface_text: The principal question for consideration is whether a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat constituted under the Orissa Act is a person in the service of the Government of the State of Orissa and belongs to the class specified in cl. f of s. 123 7 . Obviously, two things will have to be established before the provisions -of s. 123 7 f can apply to a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat constituted under the Orissa Act

issues.text: That such a person is in the service of the Government

anchor.surface_text: 1 That such a person is in the service of the Government and 2 that he comes within the class specified in cl. f . It would number be enough to establish only one of these conditions. It is necessary, therefore, to decide, in the first instance, whether a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act is a person in the service of the Government of the State of Orissa.

issues.text: that he comes within the class specified in cl. f

holdings.text: Unnecessary to decide whether provisions of Art. 133(1)(c) applied as special leave granted under Art. 136 due to considerable public importance.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us unnecessary to decide whether in a case of this kind the provisions of Art. 133 1 c of the Constitution applied because, in our opinion, even if they did number apply and the High Court companyld number have issued a certificate, this was just the kind of case where we would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution because the appeal raised a point of law of companysiderable public importance. In order to remove all doubts in the matter, we grant the appellant special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court of Orissa and proceed to deal with the appeal on that basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if Art.133(1)(c) not applicable, case warrants special leave under Art.136 for point of law of considerable public importance.

holdings.text: There is a distinction between 'serving under the Government' and 'in the service of the Government'; the latter imports master-servant relationship requiring personal service duty and right of control.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is a distinction between I serving under the Government and I in the service of the Government, because while one may serve under a Government, one may number necessarily be in the service of the Government under the latter expression one number only serves under the Government but is in the service of the Government and it imports the relationship of master and servant. There are, according to Batt On the Law of Master and Servant , two essentials to this relationship 1 The servant must be under the duty of rendering personal services to the master or to others in his behalf and 2 the master must have the right to companytrol the servants work either personally or by another servant or agent and, according to him, It is this right of companytrol or interference, of being entitled to tell the servant when to work within the hours of service or when number to work, and what work to do and how to do it within the terms of such service , which is the dominant characteristic in this relation and marks off the servant from an independent companytractor, or from one employed merely to give to his employer the fruits or results of his labour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction; applies master-servant test from Batt; govt powers supervisory over autonomous body, not personal control.

holdings.text: Sarpanch of Grama Panchayat under Orissa Grama Panchayats Act, 1948 is not a person in the service of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: We have been unable to find a single provision of the Orissa Act from which we companyld say that a Sarpanch is a person in the service of the Government.... None of the provisions of the Orissa Act suggest that as between the State Government and the Grama Panchayat and its Sarpanch any such relationship exists. It is true that the State Government, the District Magistrate and the Sub-divisional Magistrate have been given certain powers of companytrol and supervision over the Grama Panchayat but those powers of companytrol and supervision are in relation to the administrative functions of the Grama Panchayat and the Sarpanch.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elected not appointed by govt; acts under Panchayat authority; no govt remuneration; removal only for cause; analogies to municipalities, co-ops, companies; supervisory powers insufficient for service relation.

holdings.text: Sarpanch is neither a revenue officer nor a village accountant under cl. f of s.123(7).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.f descriptive of specific revenue officers/village accountants like patwaris; exclusion of other village officers; no statutory revenue functions assigned to Sarpanch.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.123(7)(f) do not apply to Sarpanch; no corrupt practice of obtaining assistance from Sarpanches established.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that in the present case the two essential elements that a Sarpanch must be a person in the service of the Government and that he belongs to the class mentioned in cl. f of sub-s. 7 of s. 123 have number been established. ... In our opinion, the provisions of s. 123 7 do number apply to him. Therefore, it cannot. be said that any companyrupt practice under s. 123 had been established in the case and the election of the appellant companyld number be set aside on the only ground on which his election had been set aside by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fails both requirements of s.123(7)(f): not in govt service and not in specified class.

holdings.text: High Court erred in holding Sarpanch within s.123(7)(f) and setting aside election on that ground.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in supposing that because a. Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act exercised governmental duties he must be regarded as a person in the service of the Government. The High Court did number give any clear finding that a Sarpanch, even if a person in the service of the Government, was either a revenue officer or a village accountant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapplied service concept; no finding on cl.f class.

holdings.text: Post-1956 amendment, s.123(7) narrower in scope than pre-amendment s.123(8), limited to specified classes.

anchor.surface_text: There is a material difference between the phraseology of s. 123 8 before it was amended and s. 123 7 as number companytained in the Act. Under the former provision there was a prohibition against obtaining any assistance... from any person serving under the Government... The language of the provisions of s. 123 8 companyered a wide field... After the amendment, however, the provisions of s. 123 7 are narrower in scope. These provisions apply to any person in the service of the Government belonging to the classes specified in cls. a to g and numbere else.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison shows shift from broad 'serving under' to specific classes in 'service of'.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed with costs; election petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the election petition of respondent No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No corrupt practice; sole ground for setting aside election fails.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; election petition dismissed; appellant's election restored as no corrupt practice found

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us unnecessary to decide whether in a case of this kind the provisions of Art. 133 1 c of the Constitution applied because, in our opinion, even if they did number apply and the High Court companyld number have issued a certificate, this was just the kind of case where we would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution because the appeal raised a point of law of companysiderable public importance. In order to remove all doubts in the matter, we grant the appellant special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court of Orissa and proceed to deal with the appeal on that basis.
The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.
The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.

anchor.surface_text: We have been unable to find a single provision of the Orissa Act from which we companyld say that a Sarpanch is a person in the service of the Government.... None of the provisions of the Orissa Act suggest that as between the State Government and the Grama Panchayat and its Sarpanch any such relationship exists. It is true that the State Government, the District Magistrate and the Sub-divisional Magistrate have been given certain powers of companytrol and supervision over the Grama Panchayat but those powers of companytrol and supervision are in relation to the administrative functions of the Grama Panchayat and the Sarpanch.
The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that in the present case the two essential elements that a Sarpanch must be a person in the service of the Government and that he belongs to the class mentioned in cl. f of sub-s. 7 of s. 123 have number been established. ... In our opinion, the provisions of s. 123 7 do number apply to him. Therefore, it cannot. be said that any companyrupt practice under s. 123 had been established in the case and the election of the appellant companyld number be set aside on the only ground on which his election had been set aside by the High Court.
The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.
